title: How to Find the Equation of a Line

steps.title: Plug the slope in for m in the formula y-y1 = m(x-x1).
steps.content: Plug the slope in for m in the formula y-y 1 = m (x-x 1 ). This is known as the point-slope formula. [1] X Expert Source Grace Imson, MA Math Teacher Expert Interview. 1 November 2019. The point-slope formula uses the slope and the coordinates of a point along the line to find the y-intercept. Use the slope in place of m in y-y 1 = m (x-x 1 ). [2] X Research source For example, if you know the slope of the line is 2, then your formula will look like this: y-y 1 = 2(x-x 1 ) .

steps.title: Replace x1 and y1 with the coordinates of the point.
steps.content: Replace x 1 and y 1 with the coordinates of the point. Use the coordinates you’re given as (x 1 , y 1 ). Put the numbers in the corresponding spot on your formula before you start solving the equation. [3] X Expert Source Grace Imson, MA Math Teacher Expert Interview. 1 November 2019.

steps.title: Solve the formula for y to get the final slope-intercept formula.
steps.content: Solve the formula for y to get the final slope-intercept formula. Follow the mathematical order of operations and the distributive property to remove the x-term from parenthesis. [4] X Expert Source Grace Imson, MA Math Teacher Expert Interview. 1 November 2019. In our example, first you’d use the distributive property to get y-3=2x-8. Then, add 3 to each side so y is by itself. The final equation for a line in slope-intercept form with a slope of 2 that contains the point (4, 3) is y = 2x-5 .

steps.title: Find the slope using m = (y2-y1)/(x2-x1).
steps.content: Find the slope using m = (y 2 -y 1 )/(x 2 -x 1 ). The ordered pairs of the coordinates you have are listed as (x, y). Use the first set of coordinates as (x 1 , y 1 ) and the second set as (x 2 , y 2 ). [5] X Research source Plug the numbers into the formula m = (y 2 -y 1 )/(x 2 -x 1 ) and solve for m . [6] X Expert Source Grace Imson, MA Math Teacher Expert Interview. 1 November 2019.

steps.title: Replace the m in the slope-intercept formula with the slope you found.
steps.content: Replace the m in the slope-intercept formula with the slope you found. The slope-intercept formula of a line is written as y = m x+b, where m is the slope and b is the y-intercept (the point on the y-axis where the line crosses it). Plug the number you found for your slope in place of m . [7] X Research source In our example, the formula would read y = 1x+b or y = x+b when you replace the slope value.

steps.title: Substitute x and y for one of the points you know to solve for the y-intercept.
steps.content: Substitute x and y for one of the points you know to solve for the y-intercept. Pick one of the ordered pairs to put into the slope-intercept formula. Put the x-value in place of x and the y-value in place of y. [8] X Research source In this example, if you chose (3, 8) as your coordinates, then the formula would read 8 = 1(3)+b .

steps.title: Solve the equation for b.
steps.content: Solve the equation for b. Once you plug the x- and y-values as well as your slope into the formula, find the value of b in the equation. Follow the order of operations first before moving the rest of the numbers to the other side. Leave b on one side of the equation to solve it. [9] X Research source In our example, the formula currently reads 8 = 1(3)+b. Multiply 1 and 3 together to get 8 = 3+b. Since 3 is a positive number, subtract 3 from each side to isolate b. This leaves you with 5 = b, or b = 5.

steps.title: Plug in the slope and y-intercept into the slope-intercept formula to finish the equation.
steps.content: Plug in the slope and y-intercept into the slope-intercept formula to finish the equation. Once you’re finished, plug in the slope for m and the y-intercept for b. After that, you’ve found the equation for the line. [10] X Research source For example, the equation for the line with points on (3, 8) and (7, 12) is y = 1x+5 or simply y = x+5 .
